author: Laura Hill
title: New service to tackle hate crime as campaigners warn Brexit has led to 'anti-immigrant' sentiment
text:
New service to tackle hate crime as campaigners warn Brexit has led to 'anti-immigrant' sentiment 16:00, 16 Oct 2016 County Durham Police and Crime Commissioner Ron Hogg has launched the country's first hate crime advocacy service Share Get daily news by email PA A Border Force officer checking passports 
Brexit has brought an ‘anti-immigrant’ sentiment to the surface, campaigners have said, as the country’s first Hate Crime Advocacy Service is launched in County Durham . 
Anti-racism campaigners say that the profile of hate crime has risen since the UK voted to leave the EU on June 23. 
Laura Pidcock, North East education team manager at Show Racism the Red Card, said: “We are acutely aware that in some places there exists a hostile environment for Black, Asian and other minority communities. 
“The climate post-Brexit has brought to the surface anti-immigrant sentiment, anti-Muslim prejudice and other discriminatory behaviours, meaning that the profile of hate crime has risen. Worryingly we know that hate crime is vastly under-reported.” 
Many fear the problem is going to get worse and avoid reporting hate crime, Miss Pidcock said. 
She added: “There are many pressures on those who are targeted, and they may fear things getting worse. Some people are also fearful of the repercussions if they report what happened.” County Durham and Darlington’s Police Crime Commissioner, Ron Hogg 
County Durham and Darlington’s Police Crime Commissioner, Ron Hogg, has put a new advocacy service in place as part of his pledge to put the victims of crime first. 
Show Racism the Red Card, Darlington Association on Disability and Gay Advice Darlington and Durham will work together as part of the scheme to support anyone suffering from hate crime, or possible hate crime, throughout the criminal justice process. 
It is hoped that with more support in place victims of hate crime would be more likely to come forward. Read More How post Brexit racial tensions are being dealt with in Newcastle 
Mr Hogg said: “A crime that is motivated by hostility or prejudice towards the victim is particularly destructive and can have devastating consequences for that victim, those closest to them and the wider community. 
“The service will support victims to ensure their rights are safeguarded and they are empowered to make informed choices and decisions about their recovery.”
